item.title: Building a Style Guide for Non-Designers
item.description:
There is something about style guides that feel integrated, tidy, and just plain clean to me. Maybe this is because I imagine that putting together graphics is just a whole lot easier when all of the font family, font size, line weights, and colors have been already decided.

And a style guide doesn't just help with graphics, it also makes document creation of all sorts easier, and everything that you output shares a consistent look and feel. There's one word that captures this, and that word is "polished."

Anyway, I've been wanting to make my own style guide for a while, but my strength is with statistics and programming, not design. But by following some guides and themes, I've managed to come up with a style guide that I quite like, and from what I can tell there are a few important design principals to follow (though again, not my expertise):

  • Header text should be a serif font (or opposite of the text)
  • Basic text should be a sans-serif font

potterzot Style Guide

item.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
item.description:
You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext and includes the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

def print_hi(name)
  puts "Hi, #{name}"
end
print_hi('Tom')
#=> prints 'Hi, Tom' to STDOUT.

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll’s dedicated Help repository.
